sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with singular matrices
message_1:
A system of linear equations is given by:

3x + 2y = 7

6x + 4y = 14

This system of equations has a singular matrix. What is the value of x and y in this system of equations?
message_2:
This system of linear equations is dependent, meaning that the two equations represent the same line. To see this, notice that the second equation is just a multiple of the first equation:

(2)(3x + 2y) = (2)(7)

6x + 4y = 14

Since the two equations represent the same line, there are infinitely many solutions for x and y that will satisfy the system. To find the relationship between x and y, we can solve for y in terms of x (or vice versa) from one of the equations. Using the first equation:

3x + 2y = 7

2y = 7 - 3x

y = (7 - 3x) / 2

Now, for any value of x, we can find the corresponding value of y that satisfies the system of equations. There is no unique solution for x and y in this case.
